Microwave synthesized quaternized celluloses for cyclic carbonate synthesis from carbon dioxide and epoxides Kuruppathparambil Roshith Roshan Tharun Jose Amal Cherian Kathalikkattil Dong Woo Kim Bomi Kim Dae Won Park ⁎ School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan 609-735, Republic of Korea School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Pusan National University Busan 609-735 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 51 510 2399; fax: +82 51 512 8563. Graphical abstract The efficacy of microwave irradiation for the quaternization of ethylenediamine-functionalized celluloses (en-Cell), as well as the catalytic activity of the resultant microwave quaternized celluloses (mQCs) in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with epoxide substrates under solvent-free conditions has been studied. A series of mQCs with various alkyl chains and anions were synthesized and characterized by solid-state 13C NMR, FT-IR, XPS, and EA. The mQCs employed were found to yield cyclic carbonates in an atom-efficient manner with excellent selectivity (99%) under a low catalytic loading (0.4mol%) and elevated pressures of CO2 (1.2MPa), thereby realizing a turnover number (TON) of 242. A quite remarkable BET surface area ranging from 50 to 71m2 g−1 for the microwave-synthesized quaternized celluloses was obtained, compared to the very low surface area of 2m2 g−1 of the starting cellulosic material. The indispensable role played by the vicinal hydroxyl groups of cellulose during catalysis was investigated using hydroxyl-protected celluloses. By rationalizing the obtained results, a plausible mechanism, in which all the functional moieties of the mQCs operate synergistically, is proposed. The mQC catalysts were found to exhibit excellent thermal and moisture stability, and they were reusable more than six times without any significant reduction in activity. Keywords Quaternized cellulose Microwave Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonate Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction As the research measures addressing the escalating levels of atmospheric CO2 are on an ever-expanding continuum, carbon capture sequestration (CCS) technologies, and the potential use of CO2 as a C1 feed stock has gained widespread interest. CO2 is thermodynamically stable and its desirable physical properties, including non-toxicity and inflammability, along with its ready abundance, have prompted researchers to employ CO2 as an environmentally benign, green substitute for harmful chemicals such as COCl2 (phosgene) and CO, on the context of environmental preservation and resource utilization [1–5]. Obvious from the ample amount of published reports worldwide, one of the more promising methodologies toward carbon sequestration is the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates using epoxide substrates (Scheme 1 ). Five-membered cyclic carbonates are industrially valuable chemicals that are widely employed as aprotic solvents, solvents in lithium ion batteries, monomer units of polycarbonates, etc. [6,7]. Despite its electrophilicity, CO2 remains unreactive with epoxides in the absence of catalytic species under most conventional reaction conditions. This challenge has led to the development of several catalyst systems, including room-temperature and task-specific ionic liquids, metal complexes of salen and porphyrins, organometallic catalysts, quaternary ammonium moieties, organic bases, and others [3,8–10]. In addition to these highly active homogeneous systems, durable and stable platforms such as commercial amorphous silica and polystyrene-supported catalysts have been explored with the purpose of imparting properties that promotes reusability [11–26]. The cooperative role of functional groups present in support materials, such as hydroxyl groups in silica as demonstrated by Takahashi et al. [13] have facilitated the introduction of a new class of supported-phase catalysis for CO2 fixation, based on hydrogen bonding at the solid–liquid interface. Subsequently, rigorous research has been conducted to find supports capable of serving the dual role of scaffold as well as possessing functional groups adept with the potential to effect the required synergism. Recently, the quest for novel renewable support materials, which can be employed as biocompatible alternatives to silica and synthetic polymeric supports, has gained momentum with the introduction of chitosan as an eco-friendly platform for ionic liquids [27,28]. The intriguing role of the vicinal hydroxyl groups of cellulose/cyclodextrin in affording high catalytic activity, in synergy with iodide species, was proposed and established experimentally and theoretically, using first-principles studies in reports by Han et al. [29–31]. Thereafter, many groups, including ours, have repeatedly tried to develop catalysts based on biopolymer systems of this type in order to exploit their versatility [32,33]. The ability of such biopolymer systems to mimic the catalytic activity of ammonium salts to an appreciable extent was proven beyond doubt by the catalysis exhibited by quaternized chitosan [34]. It has been noted that quaternization imparts to the resultant chitosan moiety a multi-fold increase in surface area; thus, a major shortcoming of low surface area, which restricts the applicability of biopolymer scaffolds in catalysis, is addressed [35]. When considering CO2 fixation mediated by hydrogen bond activators, cellulose, which is the most abundant biopolymer on earth, represents the best available choice of a renewable platform. The cellulose macromolecule is characterized by its well-defined chain lengths and its broad network of ordered intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonding. Along with its unique structure, biocompatibility, non-toxicity, reactivity, and low cost, cellulose represents a potentially renewable biopolymer for the generation of functional materials, thus ensuring sustainability. The need for the development of greener catalyst support frameworks and the nearly inexhaustible supply of cellulose makes it surprising that catalytic applications of this naturally occurring polysaccharide remain underexplored. Thus, the development of techniques to harness the advantageous properties of this flexible natural resource, which is prone to quantitative surface functionalization, would indeed offer wider opportunities for green chemistry and may form an attractive, green, sustainable, and seemingly inexhaustible alternative to synthetic organic and inorganic polymeric supports [36–38]. As a sequel to our previous work concerning quaternized chitosan-catalyzed cycloaddition, we surmised that extending the technique of quaternization to cellulose would be the appropriate course of study, as cellulose possesses an even more uniform distribution of reactive hydroxyl groups that display an exceptionally remarkable stereoregularity. Quaternized celluloses (QCs) that possess an ionic nitrogen moiety and hydroxyl groups are a class of ionic celluloses, which have been overlooked as potentially biocompatible and safe materials for drug delivery and as gene and protein carriers, but whose catalytic applicability has never been explored. A number of reports have presented the synthesis of water-soluble QC via various linkers [39–41]. With heterogeneity being a desired criterion for practical reusability, we have attempted to synthesize novel, insoluble, quaternized cellulosic derivatives using microwave radiation, so that the need for the covalent tethering of expensive, moisture- and air-sensitive catalytic species such as ionic liquids can be circumvented. The catalytic efficiency of the resultant mQCs in the solvent-free cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with propylene oxide, which yields propylene carbonate (PC) under mild reaction conditions, has been investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Microcrystalline cellulose, lithium bromide, 1,4-dioxane, N-bromosuccinimide (NBS), dimethyl acetamide (DMA), iodomethane, iodoethane, bromoethane, chloroethane, 1-iodobutane, 1-bromopropane, 1-chloropropane, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), ethylene diamine, and acetic anhydride were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. Propylene oxide (PO) and other epoxides were also obtained from Aldrich and used as received. CO2 with 99.999% purity was used without further purification. Methanol and acetone was obtained from SK Chemicals Korea and used as received. 2.2 Scheme of synthesis The methodology adopted for the synthesis of QC in this work differed from earlier reports to the extent that the amine groups anchored on the cellulose units were subjected to quaternization, rather than tethering an already quaternized moiety to the cellulose backbone. The multistep synthesis (Scheme 2 ) commenced with the regioselective bromination of cellulose as proposed by Matsui et al. [42] to yield 6-bromo-6-deoxycellulose (a; Br-Cell), followed by amination using ethylene-1,2-diamine to yield ethylenediamine-anchored cellulose (b; en-Cell) [43]. Finally, microwave irradiation was employed to carry out quaternization involving the amino groups on en-Cell using methyl iodide; the reaction proceeded quantitatively in 20min under a rather low microwave power (100W) in the presence of NaOH, yielding mQC-1.I (mQC-n.X, where “m” stands for microwave, “n” represents the length of linear alkyl chain and “X” is the halide). The experimental details are discussed below. 2.2.1 Synthesis of 6-(2′-aminoethylamino)-6-deoxycellulose (en-Cell) A sample of 1.0g Br-Cell was reacted with 5.0mL of ethylene-1,2-diamine (en) under reflux with mechanical stirring for 4h. The solution was filtered through a sintered glass filter and the solid was Soxhlet-extracted using methanol for 24h (en-Cell), and then dried in vacuum at 50°C for 24h. 2.2.2 Microwave synthesis of quaternized cellulose mQC-n.X In a typical procedure 1g of en-Cell is dispersed in 10mL of N,N-dimethyl acetamide (DMA) in a pyrex glass reactor. To this mixture, 0.12mL of NaOH (1M) and a calculated amount of alkyl halide (as in Supplementary data, S1) were added. It was then irradiated with microwave radiation at 100W for a particular time as specified in S1 (Supplementary information). Next, the solution was precipitated in excess MeOH/H2O (1:1) mixture and Soxhlet-extracted for 24h; then, it was filtered and dried at 60°C for 24h to obtain the corresponding microwave quaternized cellulose (mQC-n.X). 2.2.3 Synthesis of hydroxyl free cellulose derivatives Synthesis of 2,3-diacetoxy-6-bromo-6-deoxycellulose (AC-BrCell) was carried out as per the literature [44]. For the synthesis of 2,3-diacetoxy-6-(2′-aminoethylamino)-6-deoxycellulose, 1g AC-BrCell was reacted with 5.0mL of ethylene-1,2-diamine (en) under reflux and with stirring for 3h. The solution was precipitated in excess acetone, washed several times, and dried at 50°C for 24h to yield the desired compound. 2.3 Coupling reactions Propylene carbonate (PC) was synthesized by the coupling reaction between PO and CO2 in the presence of mQCs. All the reactions were carried out in a 60mL stainless-steel batch reactor with a magnetic stirrer at 600rpm. In a typical batch reaction process, a pre-decided amount of the catalyst was charged into the reactor containing 42.8mmol of PO. The reaction was carried out under a preset pressure of carbon dioxide at different temperatures. After the completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to 0°C, and the products were identified by a gas chromatograph (Agilent HP 6890A) equipped with a capillary column (HP-5, 30m×0.25μm) using a flame-ionized detector. The product yield was determined by using an internal standard method with biphenyl (0.05g) as the standard. 2.4 Characterization The elemental analysis (EA) was carried out using a Vario EL III system. Two milligram of the samples were subjected to analysis at 1100°C, and sulfanilic acid was used as the standard. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained on an AVATAR 370 Thermo Nicolet spectrophotometer with a resolution of 4cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a Netzsch STA 449 instrument with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 from 40°C to 800°C under a nitrogen atmosphere. A gas chromatograph (HP 6890 A), equipped with an HP-1 capillary column, was used to determine the concentration of the corresponding cyclic carbonates formed. 13C NMR spectra of the samples were obtained on a Bruker AC 300/P spectrometer at room temperature. XPS analyses were performed using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (VG, ESCALAB 250) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hν =1486.6eV). The surface area was determined by N2 adsorption at 77K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. The surface morphology was observed using a S-4200 field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Hitachi-3500N). For the catalyst synthesis, a multimode microwave reactor (KMIC-2KW) was used. This reactor contained the source with a continuously adjustable power from 0 to 2kW, and it used a three-stub tuner, operating at a frequency of 2.450GHz. The surface temperature of the reactor was measured with an IR temperature detector. 3 Results and discussion The intermediates and resultant quaternized moieties, which were prepared using the successful step-wise derivatization of cellulose, were characterized by CPMAS 13C NMR, XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy), FT-IR and elemental analysis (EA). 3.1 CPMAS 13C spectrum The CPMAS 13C spectrum of pristine microcrystalline cellulose (Fig. 1a) shows the characteristic peaks for C1 at 104ppm, C4 at 88ppm, C2, C3, and C5 at 74ppm, and C6 at 65ppm [43]. Examination of the Br-Cell spectrum (Fig. 1b) revealed a significant change in the chemical shift for C6 to 38ppm that affirmed C-Br bond formation; en-Cell (Fig. 1c) exhibited a broad peak from 42 to 50ppm [43], which is attributed to a cumulative effect of peaks corresponding to chemical shifts assigned to C6, C7, and C8. As a direct consequence of quaternization using methyl iodide, the C8 peak shifted to 60ppm owing to the deshielding effect provided by the newly methylated nitrogen atom (Fig. 1d). In addition, new peaks appearing at 56ppm could be assigned to the methyl carbons (C9) attached directly to the ammonium cation [41,45]. 3.2 FT-IR spectra FT-IR spectra of the crude cellulose and its modified biopolymers are shown in Fig. 2 . The brominated cellulose (Fig. 2b) showed the appearance of a relatively weak absorption near 550cm−1, which corresponds to the stretching vibration of the CBr bond at the branching point of the original polymer [44]. The absorption originally observed in cellulose at 894cm−1 shifted to 865cm−1, and it was accompanied by a decrease in band size in the Br-Cell compound (Fig. 2a) which disappeared entirely in en-Cell (Fig. 2c) [43]. This fact corroborates the substitution of the hydroxyl groups by bromine in this reaction. In en-Cell the vibration assigned to CH stretching of the symmetric CH2 group at 2844cm−1 strengthened; the presence of a new band at 1543cm−1, corresponding to the angular deformation of the NH amine, confirmed the successful tethering of ethylene-1,2-diamine on the cellulose surface. A prominent band at 1475cm−1 appearing for the mQC-1.I, which could be attributed to the asymmetric angular bending of N+Me3, provided direct evidence of successful quaternization [34,35,40,41]. 3.3 XPS analysis Further corroboration of successful quaternization under microwave irradiation was provided through XPS analyses (Fig. 3 ). While the en-Cell (Fig. 3a) showed a sole characteristic amine nitrogen 1s peak at 399.7eV, the quaternized species (mQC-1.I; Fig. 3b) exhibited one additional peak centered at 402.4eV, which is consistent with literature data for the 1s binding energy of quaternized nitrogen (N+Me3) species. This observation could be rationalized by the fact that the exposed primary amine groups of the en-Cell indeed underwent a successful quaternization while the secondary amine group remained unreacted. The new peak (402.4eV) observed in the characteristic region for the quaternary nitrogen atom, in addition to the peak at 399.7eV, provided conclusive evidence for the successful quaternization of the cellulose material [34,35,46]. The XPS data of the various mQC-n.X, synthesized with different alkyl chain lengths and anions, are given as Table S3. 3.4 Catalytic activity The catalytic activities of various mQCs in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide were investigated using propylene oxide as the epoxide substrate. A series of control tests were performed with the mQC precursor materials as shown in Table 1 (entries 1–8). While cellulose (entry 2) alone showed no signs of catalytic activity, cellulose/MeI (entry 3) furnished PC, although in low yield. Apparently, the partially polarized methyl iodide CI bond might have operated synergistically with the vicinal hydroxyl groups of the cellulose chain, as proposed by Liang et al. [29]. However, it is more likely that the unavailability of a free nucleophilic anion (I−) must have been the limiting factor behind the low catalytic activity. The greater activity obtained with cellulose/KI (entry 4) substantiated the above reasoning, whereas the catalytic activity of KI alone has already been reported to be below 10% under the employed reaction conditions [29]. The intermediate compounds of target species (Br-Cell and en-Cell) were also found to be catalytically inactive, with less than 4% activity. However, en-Cell gave better conversions of 73% and 27% with KI and MeI, respectively, compared to cellulose (entries 7, 8), which could be attributed to the presence of the amino groups. As per our expectations, methyl iodide-quaternized cellulose, mQC-1.I gave promising conversion of 98% , with >99% selectivity toward PC under optimized conditions of 120°C, 1.2MPa, and 3h reaction time with a nominal catalytic loading of 0.4mol% with respect to propylene oxide. Although a direct comparison with the previously reported analogous catalysts would not be entirely accurate owing to the difference in catalyst loading amounts on biopolymer supports and the variety of reaction conditions employed in the literature, the turnover number (TON) of 242 obtained with mQC-1.I at CO2 pressures as low as 1.2MPa demonstrates its pre-eminence in catalytic activity among the biopolymer-based heterogeneous catalysts reported to date, to the best of our knowledge (Table 2 ). A 3-fold increase in the TON was observed with mQC-1.I in comparison to previous reports employing chitosan [27,28,34] (Table 2, entries 1,4 and 5) and cellulose-based catalysis [29–31] (entries 2 and 3). A comparison of catalytic activity of microwave-synthesized QCs with different alkyl chain moieties and halide anions by examination of the TON figures indicated that mQCs with iodide anions (entries 7, 8, and 11) exhibited the best catalytic activity (PC yields of 92–97%) irrespective of the alkyl chain length, whereas the chloride ion showed the least yield (∼60% PC yield, entries 10 and 13), in agreement with the generally accepted order of nucleophilicity. This led to the conclusion that, while the choice of halide ion is of great significance in the outcome of the QC-catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide, the length of the alkyl chain has minimal impact. 3.4.1 Role of vicinal hydroxyl groups of cellulose Although the significance of the synergistic effect generated by interaction of cellulose vicinal hydroxyl groups and halide ions have been explored with probe molecules such as glycol and methanol, we deemed it worthwhile to investigate the possibility of extrapolating such a generalization to our catalysts as well, using its heterogeneous analogs. For this purpose, cellulose derivatives with the vicinal hydroxyl groups protected via acetylation [44] (Fig. 4 ) were synthesized, and their activities were compared with those of the corresponding cellulose derivatives containing free vicinal hydroxyl groups (Table 3 ). As can be seen, the use of hydroxyl-free derivatives (entries 3 and 4) resulted in very low propylene carbonate yields of 13% and 22% compared with the propylene carbonate yields of their hydroxyl-containing counterparts (entries 1 and 2). Furthermore, the similar activities achieved with the combination of cellulose/KI (Table 1, entry 4) and Br-Cell/KI (Table 3, entry 1) suggested that in the conversion process, the role of the cellulosic primary hydroxyl group is less significant than that of its vicinal hydroxyl groups. This corroborates the proposed seven-membered ring formation through a hydrogen-bonding network involving the vicinal hydroxyl motif and the propylene oxide oxygen during PC synthesis, as proposed by Liang et al. [29]. Despite their diminished significance with respect to reactivity, the amino groups present in the mQCs should also be considered to be contributors to reactivity as the cycloaddition proceeds, since en-Cell/KI (Table 1, entry 7) and Br-Cell/KI (Table 3, entry 1) resulted in a 13% difference in propylene carbonate yield, with the former being higher. A similar result of 9% was obtained with the acetylated cellulose derivatives and KI mixture (Table 3, entries 3 and 4), which was rather affirmative of the role of amino group participation, a phenomenon previously reported in the case of CO2 activation [28]. 3.5 Mechanism of cycloaddition with mQC-1.I Considering the above results and earlier reports [23,29,31], we attempted to arrive at a plausible mechanism (Scheme 3 ) portraying the probable sequence of events occurring in the mQC-catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with PO, yielding PC. The propylene oxide molecules approach the cellulose moiety, forming a seven-membered ring with the vicinal hydroxyl groups of the first AGU by means of hydrogen bonding, and this results in the polarization of the CO bond. The site of attack is configured in a way such that the nucleophilic anion on the second AGU, which is now on the same side of the vicinal hydroxyl group, is able to initiate an attack on the least hindered (β) carbon atom of the epoxide ring. Ring-opening of the epoxide occurs, followed by formation of a new C X covalent bond. Meanwhile, the secondary amino group on the AGU-2 coordinates with CO2 reversibly by means of its inherent nucleophilicity. This generates a carbamate ion and thereby activates the otherwise stable linear molecule. The ring-opened epoxide moiety engages in nucleophilic attack on the carbamate anion, yielding an alkyl carbonate anionic species, which eventually yields PC upon subsequent ring closure and catalyst regeneration. As can be seen, hydrogen bonding is the key chemical interaction that holds the epoxide in the right orientation to facilitate an effective nucleophilic attack by the halide anion. Hence, the improved activity of this microwave-synthesized catalyst system over previously reported biopolymer-based catalysts could be attributed to the increased accessibility of the twin hydroxyl groups toward epoxide co-ordination and to the greater CO2 diffusivity made possible by the remarkably larger surface area of mQCs obtained via microwave irradiation. To our surprise, the use of microwaves consistently furnished a higher BET surface area of 50–71m2 g−1, which is 20–30 times higher than that of the starting material, fibrous microcrystalline cellulose (Table 4 ). We believe that this can be attributed to the disruption of the extensive cellulosic intermolecular hydrogen bonding network caused by the rapid and intense heating of the polar reaction media (en-Cell/NaOH/water/alkyl halide) by microwaves, which at this instance have made a positive influence on the catalytic activity. Hence, it is interesting to note that, in addition to being a greener source of energy, microwave radiation could be suitably chosen to impart the desired catalytic materials with greater surface areas. The advantage of this quaternization technique for the generation of catalytically active support materials over the generally applied covalent tethering technique is that while the former yields an increased surface area compared to the starting polymeric scaffold, the latter leads to an overall decrease in the BET surface area of the resultant supported catalyst. For example, the immobilization of ionic species on silica has led to a considerable decrease on the order of 3–4 times in the BET surface area of the resultant material compared to the basic support material used [14–16]. The morphological change of the microcrystalline cellulose after quaternization is displayed using SEM analysis (S4). 3.6 Thermo gravimetric analysis It should be noted that even though microwave heating resulted in efficient quaternization and well-defined surface area in the resultant atom-economical catalyst, the thermal stability of the QCs were slightly inferior to those of the starting cellulose material, as evidenced by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Fig. 5 ). Cellulose showed a moderate thermal stability up to 300°C, at which point degradation occurred via pyrolytic fragmentation of the carbon skeleton, whereas the mQC-1.I showed an onset of degradation at a temperature slightly above 210°C followed by a second degradation event at nearly 310°C, similar to that of the starting biopolymer. This earlier onset of the first degradation stage must be a direct consequence of the greater degradation or depolymerization caused to the cellulose polymeric chain by the microwave pulses [43]. Fortunately, the cycloaddition reactions were found to proceed at a maximum temperature of ca. 120°C, which is much lower than the first thermal degradation temperature (∼210°C) of mQC-1.I. The TGA curve of the reused catalyst displays a pattern similar to that of the fresh catalyst; thus, it proves the stability of the catalyst system. 3.7 Reusability The catalyst could be easily recovered by simple filtration, followed by washing with methanol–water solution, and then drying. The catalyst system (mQC-1.I) was found to be reusable up to more than six times with an impressive consistency in activity (Fig. 6 ); moreover, the reaction with fresh catalyst and catalyst reused for the fifth time gave only a 6% difference in yield. The resemblances of the TGA and FT-IR data of mQC-1.I catalysts (S7 and S8) after each recycle with the fresh catalyst is affirmative of the structural stability of the catalyst under the employed reaction conditions. All these observations and results demonstrate the moisture, thermal, and chemical stability of the mQC system. 3.8 Influence of reaction parameters Fig. 7 illustrates the effect of catalyst amount on the cycloaddition reaction of PO and CO2 evaluated under otherwise identical reaction conditions, as listed. The catalytic activities were tested with amounts as low as 0.1mol% with respect to the PO amount. To our delight, mQC-1.I catalyst exhibited a high activity under a catalyst loading of 0.4mol%, which was a considerably lesser amount compared to the previously reported biopolymer-based catalysts. Presumably, this must be a cumulative result of the excellent surface area and enhanced porosity of the catalyst, ultimately rendering a better interaction of the reactant molecules with the catalytic species. A further increase in the catalyst amount up to 1mol% resulted in only a slight enhancement in the PC yield, indicating the catalyst amount of 0.4mol% to be optimal. The crucial role played by temperature in cyclic carbonate synthesis has already been well established. However, the temperature dependence of mQC catalysts was also subjected to investigation. As illustrated in Fig. 8 , the catalytic activity exhibited a steep increase from 60°C to 100°C, with 4% and 73% activity (PO conversion), respectively, reaching a maximum of 98% at 120°C. There was no significant increase in catalytic activity with further increase in temperature, and it is noteworthy to mention that throughout the temperature scans (from 60°C to 140°C), the selectivity of PC remained unchanged (>99%). Subsequently, the effect of reaction pressure on the cycloaddition reaction was investigated (Fig. 9 ). It was found that with lower CO2 pressures of 0.6MPa, the catalytic activity diminished, most likely, due to the limited diffusivity of the reactant species. The activity improved steadily with further increases in pressure up to 1.2MPa, where it attained an excellent conversion rate of 98% in 3h, with >99% selectivity. These conversions and selectivities were maintained in the range 1.2–2.5MPa; however, it was observed that CO2 pressures beyond 2.5MPa resulted in lowered mQC catalyst activity, which might have been caused by impeding active mass transport due to excess CO2 or the reduced PO concentration in the vicinity of the catalyst. Similar effects have also been reported for other catalytic systems. Fig. 10 displays the time variant graph of the QC-assisted cycloaddition of propylene oxide and CO2. The catalytic conversion rate exhibited a direct dependence on reaction time, where it was observed that the reaction progressed rapidly in the initial stages up to 3h, giving 97% PO conversion with >99% selectivity at 1.2MPa of CO2 and 120°C, which remained constant thereafter. Extended reaction times of 4–6h did not appear to have further effects on activity: hence, an optimum reaction time of 3h was chosen. 3.9 Catalytic activity of mQC-1.I on other epoxides The substrate versatility of the mQC catalysts was tested using a series of substituted epoxide substrates. Table 5 presents the epoxide conversion and the corresponding cyclic carbonate obtained at 120°C and 1.2MPa with a catalyst amount of 0.4mol%. Aliphatic terminal epoxides (entries 1–3) and the aromatic terminal epoxide styrene oxide (entry 5) cyclized efficiently with CO2 under mQC catalysis in a short time span of 3–4h. However, the internal epoxide, cyclohexene oxide (entry 4) was sluggish in its reactivity, due in part to the steric hindrance of the cyclohexene ring that inhibited the formation of any effective hydrogen bonding between the epoxide ring and the hydroxyl groups crucial for catalysis, consequently yielding only 39% conversion in 8h. 4 Conclusions A novel approach to the synthesis of quaternized celluloses, tailored for heterogeneous catalytic applications, was attempted using microwave irradiation. Validation of the molecular and structural compositions of the quaternized celluloses was achieved by CPMAS 13C NMR, FT-IR, XPS, BET, SEM, and elemental analysis. Microwave-synthesized QCs were found to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide under mild reaction conditions (0.4mol% catalyst loading, 1.2MPa CO2) to 98% completion with 99% propylene carbonate selectivity. The explicit role of the vicinal hydroxyl groups in promoting the catalysis of cycloaddition was closely investigated using hydroxyl-protected cellulose derivatives, the results of which conclusively affirmed the possibility of seven-membered ring formation at the catalyst–reagent solid–liquid interface. Moreover, it was found that microwave pulses initiated the quaternization effectively in very little time, and instigated the mQCs with remarkably high surface areas, which is understood to have a positive influence on the catalytic activity. mQCs were found to efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition of aliphatic and aromatic terminal epoxides with excellent selectivity, and they could be reused more than six times without any significant loss of activity. Considering the plentiful availability of cellulose as a renewable bio-resource, we hope that research into the design and synthesis of novel cellulose scaffolds for catalytic applications of this well-known but underused biomaterial will prompt further research into sustainable approaches for the chemical fixation of carbon dioxide. coredata.dc:description: The efficacy of microwave irradiation for the quaternization of ethylenediamine-functionalized celluloses (en-Cell), as well as the catalytic activity of the resultant microwave quaternized celluloses (mQCs) in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with epoxide substrates under solvent-free conditions has been studied. A series of mQCs with various alkyl chains and anions were synthesized and characterized by solid-state 13C NMR, FT-IR, XPS, and EA. The mQCs employed were found to yield cyclic carbonates in an atom-efficient manner with excellent selectivity (99%) under a low catalytic loading (0.4mol%) and elevated pressures of CO2 (1.2MPa), thereby realizing a turnover number (TON) of 242. A quite remarkable BET surface area ranging from 50 to 71m2 g−1 for the microwave-synthesized quaternized celluloses was obtained, compared to the very low surface area of 2m2 g−1 of the starting cellulosic material. The indispensable role played by the vicinal hydroxyl groups of cellulose during catalysis was investigated using hydroxyl-protected celluloses. By rationalizing the obtained results, a plausible mechanism, in which all the functional moieties of the mQCs operate synergistically, is proposed. The mQC catalysts were found to exhibit excellent thermal and moisture stability, and they were reusable more than six times without any significant reduction in activity.
coredata.dc:title: Microwave synthesized quaternized celluloses for cyclic carbonate synthesis from carbon dioxide and epoxides
